docs.snippet: ZERVOUDAKIS--Ioannis A., M.D., a distinguished and widely-respected obstetrician and gynecologist, passed away peacefully at his home in Manhattan on July 8, 2016. He was surrounded by his family. Dr. Zervoudakis was an Associate Attending Obstetr...
docs.lead_paragraph:
ZERVOUDAKIS--Ioannis A.,

M.D., a distinguished and widely-respected obstetrician and gynecologist, passed away peacefully at his home in Manhattan on July 8, 2016. He was surrounded by his family. Dr. Zervoudakis was an Associate Attending Obstetrician and Gynecologist at New York-Presbyterian Hospital and an Associate Professor of Clinical Obstetrics and Gynecology at Weill Cornell Medical College. Dr. Zervoudakis practiced and taught at Weill Cornell since 1971, except for the period of 1979-1991 in which he returned to Athens, Greece, to teach and practice at the Alexandra Hospital and LITO Maternity Hospital. Dr. Zervoudakis earned his Medical Degree from the University of Athens in 1963 and his Ph.D. from the National University of Athens Faculty of Medicine. After obtaining his degrees, he completed his military service as a doctor in the Greek Navy. His post- doctoral training included an internship at Coney Island Hospital, a residency and the position of Chief Resident at The New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical Center, and a Fellowship in Maternal and Fetal Medicine at Cornell University Medical College. He was born on June 17, 1943, in Greece to his parents, Dr. Andreas Zervoudakis, also an obstetrician and gynecologist, and Aliki Zervoudakis (born Papaleonardou). He devoted his life to his family and the practice of medicine and estimated that he delivered over 20,000 babies during his career. Dr. Zervoudakis specialized in high-risk obstetrics and his research lead to the development of new techniques in treating uterine fibroids. He was a pioneer of the "fetus as patient" concept. He was a two-time Lalor Foundation Fellow and grant recipient from the National Institute of Health. Dr. Zervoudakis adored classical music and was a gourmet chef. He was a true gourmand and an extraordinarily generous and kind man. He enjoyed spending time with this wife, his children and his grandchildren. In his youth he was a well-respected scout leader of the Scouts of Greece or Soma Hellinon Proskopon. Dr. Zervoudakis was a member of the Hellenic Medical Society of New York, and served on the Board of Trustees of the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity. Dr. Zervoudakis is survived by his wife of nearly 46 years Rallou, his daughters Alice, Christina and Laura, sons-in- law Jim and Adam, grandchildren Natalie, John (his namesake), Alexander and Andreas, all of Manhattan, his sister Sophia Gouras and his nephews Andreas and Konstantinos Gouras, of Athens, Greece. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Ave on Monday, July 11, 2016, from 2:00-4:00pm and 6:00-9:00pm. Funeral services on Tuesday, July 12, 2016, at Holy Trinity Cathedral at 319 East 74th Street at 11:00am, with the repast Makaria luncheon to follow. Memorial donations may be made in Dr. Zervoudakis' memory to the Hellenic Medical Society of New York at (718) 398-2440 and to Dr. Howard I. Scher's prostate cancer research at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (646) 227-3546.

docs.snippet: POWERS--Peter J. The Board of Directors of Mutual of America Life Insurance Company, together with its officers and employees, mourn the passing of Peter J. Powers, an esteemed member of the Board of Directors since 2006. Mr. Powers served with di...
docs.lead_paragraph:
POWERS--Peter J.

The Board of Directors of Mutual of America Life Insurance Company, together with its officers and employees, mourn the passing of Peter J. Powers, an esteemed member of the Board of Directors since 2006. Mr. Powers served with distinction on the Law and Corporate Governance and Nominating Committees and was appointed Chair of the Nominating Committee in 2010. Peter Powers founded Powers Global Strategies LLC, a government relations and strategic consulting firm in New York and Washington, D.C. and served as its Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. He had a long and distinguished career as an attorney, Certified Public Accountant, consultant and public servant and served as First Deputy Mayor of the City of New York under Rudolph Giuliani from 1994 to 1996. Highly respected in his field, Mr. Powers served on the boards of numerous civic and charitable organizations including the Partnership for New York City and the United Hospital Fund and was recently elected Secretary of the Council of Governing Boards, a statewide advocacy group for private colleges and universities. Mr. Powers' sound judgment, integrity and wise counsel have been invaluable to Mutual of America and have greatly contributed to its success. We who were privileged to have known him will gratefully remember his unassuming manner, dedication to service and sincere commitment to professional excellence. His wisdom and friendship will be greatly missed. While we mourn his passing, we greatly admire the manner in which he lived his life. Peter Powers, our friend and colleague, will be remembered with profound respect and affection.   Thomas J. Moran Chairman of the Board John R. Greed President and Chief Executive Officer Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

docs.snippet: CUTLER--Wallace M., formerly of New York City, died on July 3rd at age 93. He had a career as a sound engineer in the sound and motion picture industry and received an Emmy award. He was a member of Local 52 and the NYRC, The Melrose Chapter. He i...
docs.lead_paragraph:
CUTLER--Wallace M.,

formerly of New York City, died on July 3rd at age 93. He had a career as a sound engineer in the sound and motion picture industry and received an Emmy award. He was a member of Local 52 and the NYRC, The Melrose Chapter. He is survived by his son, Edward and locally his niece, Jacqueline Braunthal. Burial is private. Donations can be made to the New York Roadrunner's Club, Melrose Chapter and Local 52-Sound and Motion Picture Union.

docs.snippet: WIESEL--Elie. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the loss of Elie Wiesel, Holocaust survivor and memory keeper of the victims of Nazi persecution who used his moral authority as...
docs.lead_paragraph:
WIESEL--Elie.

The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the loss of Elie Wiesel, Holocaust survivor and memory keeper of the victims of Nazi persecution who used his moral authority as a Nobel Laureate to focus attention on global atrocities and the plight of refugees. He was a longtime supporter of the IRC, an organization founded in 1933 to aid victims of the Nazis, joining the IRC Board in 1985 and the IRC Overseers in 2004. Before joining the IRC Board, Mr. Wiesel was a member of the IRC's Citizens Commission on Indochinese Refugees--a group whose advocacy work helped lead to the passing of the U.S. Refugee Act of 1980. In 1980, Commission members visited a Cambodian refugee camp, where Mr. Wiesel explained, "I came here because nobody came when I was there. One thing that is worse for the victim than hunger, fear, torture, is the feeling of abandonment, the feeling that nobody cares, the feeling that you don't count." In 1987, the IRC honored Mr. Wiesel with the Freedom Award, presented by Liv Ullmann, for his "extraordinary service to humanity, freedom and the cause of refugees." We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. International Rescue Committee Katherine Farley and Tracy R. Wolstencroft, Co-Chairs of the Board; Timothy Geithner Chair, IRC Overseers; David Miliband, President
